'''Timothy Kealii'okaaina Awa Chang''' (born October 9, 1981) is a retired American [[American football|football]] player. He was signed by the [[Arizona Cardinals]] as an [[undrafted free agent]] in 2005. He played [[college football]] at [[Hawaii Warriors football|Hawai'i]] where he set several major college football passing records, some of which he still holds.
Chang has also been a member of the [[Detroit Lions]], [[Philadelphia Eagles]], [[Rhein Fire]], [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] and [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]].
==Early years== Born in [[Waipahu, Hawaii|Waipahu]], [[Hawaii]], Chang attended [[St. Louis School]] in [[Honolulu]] and was an honors student and a three-year letterman in football and basketball. Chang was selected a [[High school football|prep]] [[All-America]]n by eight major organizations and publications. As a member of the St. Louis School football team, Chang completed 491 passes for 7,715 yards and 87 touchdowns in his three-year career. Timmy Chang graduated from Saint Louis High School in 2000.
==College career== Following high school, Chang played five seasons (2000â2004) for the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa|University of Hawaii]] [[Hawaii Warriors football|Warriors]] where he started 50 of 53 career games at [[quarterback]]. Chang completed 1,388 of 2,436 passes (57.0 percent) for 17,072 yards and 117 [[touchdowns]], breaking the old [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Division I-A all-time records of 1,231 completions in 1,883 attempts by [[Kliff Kingsbury]] of [[Texas Tech University]] (1999â2002) and 15,031 yards by [[Ty Detmer]] of [[Brigham Young University]] (1989â91). Chang participated in 2,587 plays, breaking the old NCAA career record of 2,156 by Kingsbury. Chang's 16,910 yards in total offense broke the previous NCAA record of 14,465 by Detmer. Chang also had six [[Rush (American football)|rushing]] touchdowns and was a four-time All-[[Western Athletic Conference]] selection.
Chang currently holds the NCAA Football Bowl Subdivision all-time [[interception]] record with 80, second most total offensive yards (16,910), second most career passing yards (17,072), most career plays from scrimmage (2,587),and is sixth to [[Case Keenum]]'s 139 touchdown passes.
Chang was named the Most Valuable Player of the 2003 [[Hawaii Bowl]] in a triple-[[Overtime (sports)|overtime]] victory over the [[University of Houston]], and was named Co-MVP, with [[Chad Owens]], of the 2004 [[Hawaii Bowl]] in a victory over the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham]]. Chang was a [[Heisman Trophy]] candidate for the 2003 season and was a finalist for the [[Johnny Unitas Golden Arm Award]] award for the 2004 season.<ref name="aired">{{cite news|url=http://www.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/20090811/SPORTS/908110341/-1/sportsfront|title=Chang aired it out for Warriors|last=Tsai|first=Stephen|date=2009-08-11|newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser|accessdate=2009-08-21}}</ref> He made a cameo in [[NCAA Football 06]] in an opening.
==Professional career== Chang was signed by the [[Arizona Cardinals]] after going undrafted in the [[2005 NFL Draft]], but was cut in [[National Football League Training Camp|training camp]]. That year, Chang also played in the preseason for the [[Detroit Lions]] but did not make the [[2005 Detroit Lions season#Final roster|final roster]]. He then signed with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]], who allocated him to the [[NFL Europe]] in [[2006 NFL season|2006]]. He played for the [[Rhein Fire]] of [[NFL Europa]] for the 2006 season, in which he completed 50 of 89 passes for 656 yards, 4 touchdowns and 3 interceptions, while sharing playing time with [[Drew Henson]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timmy-chang.com/Timmy-Chang-Rhein-Fire-2006-Passing-Stats.html|title=Timmy Chang NFL Europe Stats|accessdate=2007-05-20}}</ref> He was in training camp with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] in 2006, but was cut before the start of the regular season.
The [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]] of the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]] acquired the negotiating rights to Chang in a February 12, [[2007 CFL season|2007]] trade with the [[Edmonton Eskimos]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/story/2007/02/13/cfl-ham-edm-trade.html |title=Tiger-Cats ship Goss to Edmonton |publisher=Cbc.ca |author=CBC Sports |date= 2007-02-13|accessdate=2008-10-27}}</ref> Chang signed with Hamilton on March 13, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ticats.ca/index.php?module=newser&func=display&nid=15579 |title=Hamilton Tiger-Cats :: Official Site of the Tiger-Cats |publisher=Ticats.ca |date=Monday, October 27, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-27}}</ref> <ref>http://www.TimmyChang.net</ref> During the 2007 season, he started two of 18 games played, completing 42 of 89 pass attempts for 467 yards, one touchdown, and seven interceptions. Chang played in his first regular season game on June 30, 2007 against the [[Calgary Stampeders]] when he replaced the struggling [[Jason Maas]] towards the end of the fourth quarter, completing his first career CFL pass, a 51-yard pass to Jesse Lumsden, overall finishing 4 of 7 for 86 yards. He threw his first career CFL touchdown on July 14 during the Ticats 29-20 loss to Montreal, a 71-yard pass to Brock Ralph.
Chang was released by the Tiger-Cats on August 29, 2008 and signed by the Winnipeg Blue Bombers the following day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=248074&lid=sublink01&lpos=headlines_main |title=Blue Bombers agree to terms with QB Chang |publisher=Tsn.ca |date= |accessdate=2008-10-27}}</ref> He retired in 2009 and returned to the University of Hawaii to complete his bachelor's degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.starbulletin.com/quickreads/?p=301|title=Back to UH for Timmy Chang| publisher=StarAdvertiser.com |date=2009-05-30|accessdate=2011-04-02}}</ref>
== Personal life == On July 2, 2009, Chang was arrested at his Mililani home on suspicion of robbery. Honolulu police say a woman was filming a fight in the Pearlridge area and when Chang told the woman to stop filming it, a struggle ensued and the suspect allegedly took the camera and threw it on the roof of a nearby building. Chang has been released pending further investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/2009-07-03-chang-arrested_N.htm|title=NCAA career passing yards leader, ex-Hawaii QB Chang arrested|author=The Associated Press|date=2009-07-03|publisher=USA TODAY|accessdate=2009-07-04}}</ref> Chang was booked on criminal property damage and harassment, and pleaded guilty to both crimes in February 2010. His plea deal includes six months probation and requires him to attend an anger management assessment.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kitv.com/r/24401656/detail.html|title=Former UH QB Timmy Chang Reaches Plea Deal|author=KITV Honolulu|date=2010-07-26|publisher=KITV Honolulu|accessdate=2010-08-28}}</ref>
